awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Quantum Control of Molecular Interactions with External Electromagnetic Fields: From Few to Many-Body Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultracold molecular gases hold potential for transformative applications across physics and chemistry, ranging from quantum information processing and quantum simulation of novel materials to probing and controlling chemical reactions with external electromagnetic fields. This proposal explores two exciting frontiers recently made available by pioneering experiments at the host institution (JILA Physics Frontier Center). First, we intend to explore how the relative orientation of approaching molecules affects the outcome of a molecular collision or chemical reaction. Second, we propose to study the properties of an artificial crystal of polar molecules in an optical lattice, an exquisite quantum-many body system recently realized experimentally at the host institution. The proposed research will enhance our understanding of how electrons behave in real materials (a key goal of modern condensed-matter physics and material science) and to novel ways to control chemical reactions with electromagnetic fields (an important goal of modern chemical physics).

This proposal aims to address two outstanding open problems in the physics and chemistry of cold molecular gases: (i) the lack of understanding and control of quantum stereodynamics of low-temperature  molecular collisions in the presence of external electromagnetic fields, and (ii) the nature of the phase diagram of an ultracold gas of chemically reactive polar molecules in an optical lattice recently created  for the first time at the host institution (JILA Physics Frontier Center). Using numerically exact quantum theory of molecular collisions, we propose to elucidate the effects of external fields on the stereodynamics of cold molecular collisions, with a focus on  Ne-OH collisions currently studied experimentally at JILA. We also plan, by taking advantage of recent developments in computational condensed-matter physics, to explore the phase diagram of the extended dissipative Fermi-Hubbard model of ultracold KRb molecules in a two-dimensional optical  lattice. The proposed research may lead to new ways to control the quantum dynamics of molecular  collisions and to engineer novel quantum many-body states with ultracold molecules in optical lattices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Recent experimental advances in cooling and trapping ultracold molecular gases are harnessing the truly outstanding diversity of molecular structure and interactions  to build the hardware components of a quantum computer and to engineer quantum many-body states of extraordinary complexity. In particular, recent experiments have probed the stereodynamics of cold molecular collisions, i.e., the extent to which the relative angle of approach of  the reactants determines the outcome of a bimolecular collision or a chemical reaction.  Additionally, quantum many-body interactions of ultracold polar molecules in optical lattices have been a topic of major interest in the context of quantum information science. Both the two-body collisions and many-body collective dynamics are poorly understood theoretically.

 As such, the major objectives of this proposal were to (i) develop a theoretical understanding of quantum stereodynamics of low-temperature atom-molecule collisions in the presence of external electromagnetic fields, and (ii) explore quantum many-body physics of ultracold polar molecules in an optical lattice.

 The first goal was accomplished by performing numerically exact quantum scattering calculations on Ne-OH collisions in an external electric field based on a high-quality ab initio interaction potential. The results show extensive control over the stereodynamics of cold Ne-OH collisions in an external electric field, opening up a variety of experimental possibilities to studying field-controlled collision stereodynamics related in future experiments 

The second goal was addressed by developing a tight-binding model for KRb molecules trapped in an optical lattice. It was shown that KRb molecules interact via the long-range Ising interaction, which can be used to generate robust many-body entanglement in the form of cluster and spin-squeezed states of molecular nuclear spins. These many-body entangled states are useful for measurement-based quantum computation and for quantum-enhanced precision metrology. Our results thus open up a host of possibilities for using molecular entangled states for these applications.

 In addition to accomplishing the above research goals, the work supported by this grant has led to two major results. First, we found that long-range electric dipolar  interactions between polar alkali-dimer molecules can be efficiently controlled with dc magnetic fields in the quantum ergodic regime, where molecular wavefunctions are delocalized over many quantum states [3]. Second, we succeeded in computing the energy level spectrum of a large fullerene  molecule C60 including all tensor interactions up to the 10-th order. This has resulted in the discovery of quantum ergodic transitions in C60 as a function of the total angular momentum quantum number J [4].

The PI visited the host institution (JILA) in 2021 and 2022, and UNR graduate student Rebekah Hermsmeier visited JILA in November 2022.  The PI gave 2 contributed talks at DAMOP and 2 invited presentations. This research project resulted in a total of 4 research papers resulted from the project (two published [1-2], one accepted [4], and one about to be submitted [3]).

The award supported the professional development of the PI and one graduate student and UNR (Rebekah Hermsmeier) through long-term research visits to the host institution. The PI broadened his scientific expertise to include quantum many-body physics and established new research collaborations, which will continue after the end of the award. The student received excellent training in theoretical and computational AMO physics.

 

[1] T. V. Tscherbul and J. Kłos, Universal stereodynamics of cold atom-molecule collisions in electric fields, Phys. Rev. A 103, 062810 (2021).

[2] T. V. Tscherbul, A. M. Rey, and J. Ye, Robust nuclear spin entanglement via dipolar interactions in polar molecules, Phys. Rev. Lett. 130, 143002 (2023).

[3] R. Hermemeier, A. M. Rey, and T. V. Tscherbul, Magnetically tunable electric dipolar interactions and ac Stark shifts of ultracold alkali dimer molecules, Phys. Rev. Lett., to be submitted (2023).

[4] L. R. Liu, D. Rosenberg, P. B. Changala, P. J. D. Crowley, D. J. Nesbitt, N. Y. Yao, T. V. Tscherbul, and J. Ye, Ergodicity breaking in rapidly rotating C60 fullerenes, arXiv:2305.05324v1.


Last Modified: 08/11/2023
Modified by: Timur Tscherbul
